column14: Dame Millicent Garrett Fawcett (1847-1929) Pioneer of women's suffrage lived and died here
column16: Dame Millicent Garrett Fawcett (1847-1929) was an English suffragist and pioneer for women's rights. Born in Adleburgh, Suffolk to wealthy parents, Fawcett, through her marriage to an MP, became involved in women's political campaigns. She was elected president of the National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies (NUWSS) in 1890, a position she held until 1919. The NUWSS took a more moderate stance to their contemporaries the suffragettes, but nevertheless campaigned tirelessly for the vote for women, which was achieved for women over 30 in 1918. Fawcett is considered to be instrumental to this change.

column14: Sir Edward Burne-Jones 1833-1898 artist lived here 1865-1867
column16: Sir Edward Burne-Jones (1833-1898) was a British artist and designer closely associated with the later phase of the Pre-Raphaelite movement. Burne-Jones also created a number of famed stained glass works, as well as paintings. Working with his contemporaries Dante Gabriel Rossetti and William Morris, with whom he founded Morris, Marshall, Faulkner, and Company, Burne-Jones is considered one of the most influential artists of the 19th century. An abiding interest in the decorative arts, he also designed ceramic tiles, jewellery, tapestries, mosaics and book illustrations. Burne-Jones lived in Kensington Square for two years: his daughter was born there.

column14: Walter Sickert 1860-1942 Painter and etcher lived and worked here
column16: Walter Richard Sickert (1860-1942) was a painter who had an important influence on distinctively British styles of avant-garde art in the 20th century. Sickert was a cosmopolitan and eccentric artist who often favoured ordinary people and urban scenes as his subjects. His oeuvre also included well-known personalities and images derived from press photographs. Sickert took a keen interest in the crimes of Jack the Ripper, believing he had lodged in a room used by the serial killer. Several historians now claim that Sickert was in fact Jack the Ripper, or his accomplice.

column14: Ivor Novello (1893-1951) Composer and Actor Manager lived and died in a flat on the top floor of this building
column16: Ivor Novello (1893-1951) was a composer, actor, theatre manager and singer who became one the most influential British entertainers of the first half of the 20th century. Born into a musical family, his first successes were as a songwriter. His first big hit was "Keep the Home Fires Burning", which was enormously popular during the First World War. After the war, Novello contributed numbers to several successful musical comedies, wrote complete scores for shows and then turned to acting in the twenties. Four years after his death the Ivor Novello Awards for song writing were established in his memory.

column14: Bertrand Russell (1872-1970) Philosopher and Campaigner for Peace lived here in flat No.34 1911-1916
column16: Bertrand Russell (1872-1970) was a British philosopher, logician, social critic and campaigner for peace. Born in Monmouthshire and educated at Trinity College, Cambridge Russell made several key contributions to twentieth century mathematics and philosophy, and is considered by many to have led the British "revolt against idealism". Russell lived in this house during the First World War during which time he was prominent in the anti-war movement. Russell established the Russell Tribunal during the Vietnam War, it is now known as the International War Crimes Tribunal.

column14: Joseph Grimaldi (1778-1837) Clown lived here. *Best known for his invention of the modern day whiteface clown
column16: Joseph Grimaldi (1778-1837) was an English actor and comedian who is perhaps best known for his invention of the modern day whiteface clown. He was born into a family  of performers, and made his stage debut aged three. As a pantomime clown Grimaldi was considered unsurpassable, his greatest success occurring in "Harlequin and Mother Goose; or the Golden Egg" at Theatre Royal, Covent Garden. He was an innovator, his performance as Joey introduced the modern clown to the world and to this day clowns gather once a year at Holy Trinity Church in Dalston, London in full attire to celebrate his life.

column14: In 1926 in this house John Logie Baird 1888-1946 first demonstrated television.
column16: John Logie Baird (1888-1946) was a Scottish engineer who is most famous for first demonstrating a working television. The plaque on Frith Street commemorates this momentous achievement. Baird show ingenuity from an early age, rigging a telephone exchange from his bedroom to communicate with friends from across the street. It was in the early 1920s that Baird made his major breakthrough with transmitting moving images, and on the top floor of the Frith Street house, first demonstrated transmission to members of the Royal Institution and a reporter from the Times newspaper. Baird later went on to make contributions to colour television and even 3D.

column14: Anna Freud (1895-1982) Pioneer of Child Psychoanalysis lived here 1938-1982
column16: Anna Freud (1895–1982) was the sixth and last child of Sigmund and Martha Freud. Born in Vienna, she followed the path of her father and contributed to the newly born field of psychoanalysis. Alongside Melanie Klein, she may be considered the founder of psychoanalytic child psychology. Anna moved to Hampstead after fleeing Austria and the harassment of Jews by the Nazis in 1938. Much of her important work with children occurred during and immediately after the Second World War, observing the effects of stress and lack of parental care on children.

column14: Richard Burton (1925-1984) Actor lived here 1949-1956
column16: Richard Burton (1925-1984) was a Welsh actor who appeared in over seventy films, and was nominated for seven Academy Awards. Burton is perhaps best known for his relationship, and two marriages, to Elizabeth Taylor, who first appeared with him in "Cleopatra" in 1964. Burton lived in this house while appearing in several British films and stage productions, having served for the RAF in the Second World War, and in 1952 successfully made the transition to Hollywood star in "My Cousin Rachel," his first Oscar nomination.

column14: John Lennon (1940-1980) Musician and Songwriter lived here in 1968
column16: John Lennon (1940-1980) was an English musician and songwriter, who rose to worldwide fame as a member of the Beatles in the 1960s and then as a solo artist in the 1970s. As well as considerable success as a pop musician, Lennon also made a significant impact on the anti-war campaign during the Vietnam war. Lennon was assassinated by a fan outside his New York apartment in 1980. Lennon lived in his house on Montagu Square in 1968, the same year that the Beatles recorded "The White Album", following a visit to Maharishi Mahesh Yogi in India.

column14: Sir Henrry Wood (1869-1944) Musician lived here * best known for his assocaition with the Proms, which were renamed the Henry Wood Promenade concerts after his death
column16: Sir Henry Joseph Wood (1869-1944) was an English conductor best known for his association with London's annual series of promenade concerts, known as the Proms. He conducted them for nearly half a century, introducing hundreds of new works to British audiences. After his death, the concerts were officially renamed in his honour as the "Henry Wood Promenade Concerts," although they continued to be generally referred to as "the Proms."

column14: Ralph Vaughan Williams O.M. (1872-1958)Composer lived here from 1953 until his death
column16: Ralph Vaughan Williams (1872-1958) was an English composer of symphonies, chamber music, opera, choral music, and film scores. Educated at Cambridge, and later a pupil of the Royal College of Music, Williams made a considerable contribution to English music. Arguably, his career's greatest achievement was the work for "The English Hymnal," a collection of hymns in the English language. Williams also toured the British countryside collecting traditional folk songs. Williams lived in the house on Hanover Terrace after his second marriage to Ursula Wood from 1953 until his death five years later.

column14: David Edward Hughes (1831-1900) Scientist and inventor of the microphone lived and worked here
column16: David Edward Hughes (1831-1900) was a British scientist, inventor and musician. Throughout the nineteenth century Hughes was responsible for some of the most important inventions of the modern age. His printing telegraph system, invented in the USA in 1855, was developed into the international standard Hughes' Telegraph System. Hughes was also responsible for critical work in the transmission of radio signal, discovering in 1879 that a radio signal could be detected from sparks by listening to a telephone receiver connected to his new microphone design.

column14: Sir George Cayley (1773-1857) Scientist and pioneer of aviation lived here * Known as the father of aerodynamics
column16: Sir George Cayley (1773-1857) was a prolific English engineer and one of the most important people in the history of aeronautics - he is known as the father of Aerodynamics. Cayley designed the first ever glider to successfully carry a human aloft and discovered and identified the aerodynamic forces of flight: weight, lift, drag and thrust. Modern aeroplane design is based on those principles, as well as his invention, cambered wings.

column14: Ada Countess of Lovelace 1815-1852 Pioneer of Computing lived here
column16: Augusta Ada King, Countess of Lovelace (1815 – 1852), born Augusta Ada Byron, was an English writer chiefly known for her work on Charles Babbage's early mechanical general-purpose computer, the analytical engine. Her notes on the engine include what is recognised as the first algorithm intended to be processed by a machine; thanks to this, she is sometimes considered the "World's First Computer Programmer."

column14: Guglielmo Marconi (1874-1937) The pioneer of wireless communication lived here in 1896-1897
column16: Guglielmo Marconi (1874-1937) was an Italian inventor, known as the father of long distance radio transmission and for his development of Marconi's law and a radio telegraph system. Marconi is often credited as the inventor of radio, having built upon previous experimentation and the commercial exploitation of ideas of others. As well as his commercial successes, it was the transmission of radio signal across the Atlantic for which Marconi is known as a true innovator. He lived in this house with his mother in 1896 to seek support for his early work, and it was in London that he met the chief electrical engineer of the Post Office, William Preece.

column14: Eleanor Rathbone (1872-1946) Pioneer of Family Allowances lived here
column16: Eleanor Rathbone (1872-1946) was an independent British Member of Parliament and long-term campaigner for women's rights. Her early life focused on women's political and social rights which was heavily influenced by her research into the lives of the poor in Liverpool. After the First World War, Rathbone continued her campaign for social reform and grew increasingly concerned with international developments, notably the Spanish Civil War and the nature of Nazi Germany. She died in 1946, a year after the Family Allowances Act became law.

column14: William Smith (1756-1835) Pioneer of religious liberty lived here
column16: William Smith (1756 – 1835) was a leading independent British politician, sitting as Member of Parliament (MP) for more than one constituency. He was an English Dissenter and was instrumental in bringing political rights to that religious minority. He was a friend and close associate of William Wilberforce and a member of the Clapham Sect of social reformers, and was in the forefront of many of their campaigns for social justice, prison reform and philanthropic endeavour, most notably the abolition of slavery. He was the maternal grandfather of pioneer nurse and statistician Florence Nightingale.

column14: Alan Turing (1912-1954) Code-breaker and Pioneer of Computer Science was born here
column16: Alan Mathison Turing (1912 – 1954), was an  English mathematician, logician, cryptanalyst, and computer scientist. He was highly influential in the development of computer science, providing a formalisation of the concepts of "algorithm" and "computation" with the Turing machine, which played a significant role in the creation of the modern computer. Turing is widely considered to be the father of computer science and artificial intelligence. Turing's work during the Second World War at Bletchley Park was crucial to the breaking of the German Enigma Code.

column14: George Frideric Handel (1685-1759) Composer lived in this house from 1723 and died here
column16: George Frederic Handel (1685-1759) was a German-British Baroque composer, famous for his operas, oratorios, anthems and organ concertos who is regarded as one of the greatest composers of all time. His early career was dominated by Italian opera, but it is his English choral work for which he is perhaps best known. These include "Messiah" and "Zadok the Priest." Handel moved to this house in 1723 which he rented for the rest of his life.

column14: Jimi Hendrix (1942-1970) Guitarist and songwriter lived here 1968-1969
column16: James Marshall "Jimi" Hendrix (1942-1970) was an American guitarist and singer-songwriter. He is widely considered to be the greatest electric guitarist in music history, and one of the most influential musicians of his era. Hendrix was a pioneer of performance and music production, popularising the use of the wah-wah pedal in mainstream rock and the technique of guitar amplifier feedback. Hendrix gained an early and enthusiastic following in London, and it was here on Brook Street where he lived for a year with girlfriend Kathy Etchingham in 1969.

column14: In a house on this site in 1764-5 Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart 1756-1791 lived, played and composed
column16: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (1756-1791) was an Austrian composer, widely recognised as one of the greatest in the history of Western classical music. He composed over 600 works in every musical genre of his time. Mozart showed prodigious talent from an early age, and began composing at the age of five. Mozart travelled to London in 1764-5 where he met Johann Christian Bach, youngest son of J S Bach, who was a key influence.

column14: In this house formerly a Royal residence lived Lord Palmerston (1784-1865) Prime Minister and Foreign Secretary
column16: Henry John Temple, 3rd Viscount Palmerston (1784-1865) known popularly as Lord Palmerston was a British statesman who served twice as Prime Minister in the mid-19th century. Nicknamed "the Mongoose" he was in government office almost continuously from 1807 until his death in 1865, beginning his career as a Tory and concluding it a Liberal. He is best remembered for his direction of British foreign policy when Britain was at the height of its power. He was the most recent British Prime Minister to die in office.

column14: Samuel Morse 1791-1872 American painter, and inventor of the Morse Code lived here 1812-1815
column16: Samuel Finley Breese Morse (1791-1872) was an American painter and inventor, known for co-inventing Morse code, as well as contributing to the invention of a single-wire telegraph system. In 1825, Morse was heartbroken in the knowledge that for days he was unaware of his wife's failing health, having been notified by horse-messenger, and her lonely death: he moved on from painting to pursue a means of rapid long distance communication.  Witnessing various experiments with  electromagnetism, Morse developed the concept of a single-wire telegraph. In time the Morse code would become the primary language of telegraphy in the world, and is still the standard for rhythmic transmission of data.

column14: Edith Cavell 1865-1915 Pioneer of Modern Nursing in Belgium and Heroine of the Great War trained and worked here 1896-1901
column16: Edith Cavell (1865-1915) was a British nurse and patriot. She is celebrated for saving the lives of soldiers from all sides without distinction and in helping some 200 Allied soldiers escape from German-occupied Belgium during World War One, for which she was subsequently arrested. She was court-martialled, found guilty of treason and sentenced to death by firing squad, despite great international condemnation. It was here at the former London Hospital that Cavell trained as a nurse.

column14: Jospeh Priestley 1733-1804 Scientist, Philosopher and Theologian was Minister to the Gravel Pit Meeting here in 1793-1794 * credited with the discovery of oxygen
column16: Joseph Priestley (1733-1804) was an eighteenth century English scientist and theologian. During his lifetime, Priestley's considerable scientific reputation rested on his invention of soda water in 1767, his writings on electricity, and his discovery of several gases, most notably oxygen, first publishing his experiments on "dephlogisticated air" in 1774. Priestley's work was heavily influenced on his religious beliefs and it was Priestley who founded the firstly avowedly Unitarian congregation in London in 1774. His beliefs were controversial, however, and he was forced to flee to the United States.

column14: Rudyard Kipling (1865-1936) poet and story writer lived here 1889-1891
column16: Rudyard Kipling (1865-1936) was an English poet and writer. He is chiefly known for his works of fiction including "The Jungle Book" and the "Just So" stories, poetry and regarded as a "major innovator in the art of the story." Kipling was one of the most popular writers in England in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries and was the youngest recipient of the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1907. Kipling travelled widely, and his time spent here in London where he wrote short stories for several magazines.

column14: William Daniell (1769-1837) Artist and engraver of Indian scenes lived and died here
column16: William Daniell RA (1769–1837) was an English landscape and marine painter, and engraver. He travelled extensively in the Far East, helping to produce one of the finest illustrated volumes of the period - "Oriental Scenery." He also travelled around the coastline of Britain to paint watercolours for the equally ambitious book "A Voyage Round Great Britain." His work was exhibited at the Royal Academy and the British Institution and he became a Royal Academician in 1822. Daniell excelled in transferring his pictures to prints using the aquatint technique, and published several key works.

column14: Captain Matthew Flinders, R.N. 1774-1814) Explorer and Navigator lived here *after circumnavigating Australis encouraged the use of that name for the continent, which had previously been known as New Holland
column16: Captain Matthew Flinders (1774-1814) was one of the most successful navigators and cartographers of his age. Inspired by Daniel Defoe's "Robinson Crusoe" Flinders was the first explorer to circumnavigate Australia, and encouraged the use of that name for the continent, which had previously been known as New Holland. Flinders also invented the use of iron bars to be used to compensate for the magnetic deviations caused by iron on board a ship; they are now known as Flinders Bars.

column14: John Harrison 1693-1776 inventor of the Marine Chronometer lived and died in a house on this site
column16: John Harrison (1693-1776) was a self-educated carpenter and later a clockmaker. He is most famously known for his invention, and life-long work, of the marine chronometer in 1737; a long-sought device in solving the problem of establishing the East-West position (or longitude) of a ship at sea, thus revolutionising and extending the possibility of safe long distance sea travel in the eighteenth century. Harrison spent his last years in Red Lion Square and is burid in the graveyard of St John's Church, Hampstead.

column14: Site of the business premises of Thomas Earnshaw 1749-1829 noted watch and chronometer maker
column16: Thomas Earnshaw (1749-1829) was an English watchmaker who following John Arnold's earlier work, further simplified the process of marine chronometer production, making them available to the general public. He is also known for his improvements to the transit clock at the Royal Greenwich Observatory in London and his invention of a chronometer escapement and a form of bimetallic compensation balance, for this he is known as a pioneer of chronometer development. An Earnshaw chronometer was used aboard HMS Beagle, during Charles Darwin's voyage that inspired his theory of evolution.

column14: John Desmond Bernal 1901-1971 Crystallographer lived and died here * known for pioneering X-ray crystallography in molecular biology
column16: John Desmond Bernal (1901-1971) was a British physicist known for his studies of the atomic structure of solid compounds, during which he made major contributions to X-ray crystallography. At Cambridge University, Bernal initiated a research program of X-ray investigations into the structure of complex biological molecules that resulted in Nobel-level discoveries by his students and co-workers. Bernal also made a significant contribution to the Normandy landings of World War Two, comprehensively mapping the coast line and helping design an artificial harbour called the Mulberry.

column6: Biological Sciences Building, University College, (site of 110) Gower Street
column14: Charles Darwin 1809-1882 Naturalist lived in a house on this site 1838-1842
column16: Charles Robert Darwin (1809-1882) was an English naturalist who has been described as one of the most influential figures in human history. Darwin established that all species of life have descended over time from common ancestry, and proposed that the scientific theory that this branching pattern of evolution resulted from a process he called natural selection. Darwin lived in a house formerly occupying this site from 1838-1842, a time when he first conceived his theory of natural selection.

column14: A.W. HOFMANN 1818-1892 Professor of Chemistry lived here
column16: August Wilhelm von Hofmann (1818-1892) was a German chemist. In 1845 a school of practical chemistry was started in London, under the style of the Royal College of Chemistry, Hofmann, largely through the influence of Prince Albert, was appointed its first director. It was known as the Royal College of Chemistry and eventually became part of Imperial College London. As well as his considerable contribution to chemistry, Hofmann was also the first to introduce molecular models into public lecturers in around 1860 and his colour scheme is still in use today: carbon = black, hydrogen = white, nitrogen = blue, oxygen = red, chlorine = green, and sulphur = yellow.

column14: AUGUSTUS SIEBE 1788-1872 Pioneer of the Diving Helmet lived and worked here
column16: Augustus Siebe (1788-1872) was a German-born British engineer chiefly known for his contributions to diving equipment. Siebe moved to London in 1816 where he became a watchmaker, then gun maker, then instrument maker and settled at 5 Denmark Street where he became an engineer in 1826. Siebe began designing and building diving equipment in 1830 when he was approached by the Deane brothers, producing a helmet fitted to a full length watertight canvas diving suit. This design became standard diving dress which revolutionised underwater civil engineering, underwater salvage, commercial diving and naval diving.

column14: Ebenezer Howard 1850-1928 Pioneer of the Garden City Movement
column16: Sir Ebenezer Howard (1850-1928) is known for his publication "Garden Cities of Tomorrow" (1898), the description of a utopian city in which people live harmoniously together with nature. Howard's vision was of a city of 32,000 people on a site of 6000 hectares planned on a concentric pattern with open spaces, public parks and six radial boulevards extending from the centre. The publication resulted in the founding of the garden city movement, that realised several garden cities in Great Britain following the passing of the New Towns Act in 1946. The movement was also of great influence in America.

column6: Camden School for Girls, Sandall Road
column14: Frances Mary Buss 1827-1898 Pioneer of Education of Women was Headmistress here 1879-1894
column16: Frances Mary Buss (1827-1894) was a headmistress and an English pioneer of women's education. Buss was at the forefront of campaigns for the endowment of girls' schools, and for girls to be allowed to sit public examinations and to enter universities, as well as women's right to vote. The daughter of Robert William Buss and Frances Fleetwood, Buss attended a local free school where she began teaching at the age of fourteen. After training at Queen's College, Buss established the North London Collegiate School for Girls in 1850, which soon developed an excellent reputation for its teaching, and Camden School for Girls in 1871, where she was headmistress until her death in 1894.

column14: George Orwell (1903-1950) Novelist and political essayist lived here
column16: Eric Arthur Blair (1903-1950) better known by his pen name George Orwell, was an English novelist and journalist. Considered perhaps the 20th century's best chronicler of English culture, Orwell wrote literary criticism, poetry, fiction and polemical journalism. He is best known for the dystopian novel Nineteen Eighty-Four (1949) and the allegorical novella Animal Farm (1945), which together have sold more copies than any two books by any other 20th-century author. Orwell's influence on popular and political culture endures, and several of his neologisms, along with the term Orwellian — a byword for totalitarian or manipulative social practices — have entered the vernacular.

column14: FORD MADOX BROWN 1821-1893 Painter lived here
column16: Ford Madox Brown (1821-1893) was an English painter of moral and historical subjects, notable for his distinctly graphic version of the Pre-Raphaelite style. Brown's early work was greatly admired by the young Dante Gabriel Rossetti who asked Brown to tutor him. Although not a member of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, Brown remained closely linked to them. Brown's most famous painting is arguably "Work" which attempts to depict the totality of the mid-Victorian social experience in a single image.

column14: Thomas Hosmer Shepherd 1793-1864 Artist who portrayed London lived here
column16: Thomas Hosmer Shepherd (1792 – 1864) was a watercolour artist well known for his architectural works. Brother of topographical artist George "Sidney" Shepherd, Thomas was employed to illustrate architecture in London, and later Edinburgh, Bath and Bristol. His paintings were the basis for steel engravings in many books.Shepherd's work, mostly topographical, is characterized by an attention to detail, along with life-like scenes that contained people, carriages and horses. He worked mostly for Frederick Crace, who employed him to paint old London buildings prior to their demolition, with much of the work surviving in the Crace collection at the British Museum

column14: Sir Geoffrey Jellicoe 1900-1996 Landscape Architect lived here 1936-1984 * Best-known English landscape architect of his generation
column16: Sir Geoffrey Jellicoe (1900-1996) was an English landscape architect, garden designer, architect and designer. Jellicoe was born in Chelsea and studied at the Architectural Association in London before travelling to Rome in 1923. It was in Italy that Jellicoe's work on renaissance gardens, which were in a state of decay at that time, inspired much of his landscape architecture. Some of his key design projects included the design of new town Hemel Hempstead in 1947, Ditchley Park in Oxfordshire, Sutton Place in Surrey and the design of the John F Kennedy memorial in Egham, Surrey.

column14: Mary Kingsley (1862-1900) Traveller and ethnologist lived here as a child
column16: Mary Henrietta Kingsley (1862-1900) was an English writer and pioneering explorer of west Africa, who greatly influenced European ideas about Africa and African people. Having lived a sheltered life and never marrying, Kingsley travelled to west Africa following the death of her father George Kingsley.  It was highly unusual for a woman of Kingsley's race, age and gender to embark on such a dangerous journey unaccompanied and despite several close encounters with crocodiles, cannibalistic tribesmen and disease Kingsley's publications and lectures were remarkably modest. She made a significant impact on ideas of the colonialism of Africa. Kingsley died working as a nurse during the Boer War and was interred at sea in accordance with her wishes.

column14: William Richard Lethaby (1857-1931) Architect lived here 1880-1891 * highly influential in the late Arts and Crafts and early Modern movements in architecture
column16: William Richard Lethaby (1857 - 1931) was an English architect and architectural historian whose ideas were highly influential on the late Arts and Crafts and early Modern movements in architecture, and in the fields of conservation and art education. Born in 1857 at Barnstaple, Lethaby was the son of a carver and gilder. He studied at the local art school and in architects' offices in Barnstaple and Derby, winning the R.I.B.A.'s Sloane Medallion 1879 and the Pugin Studentship 1881. It was here in London that Lethaby founded the Central School of Arts and Crafts, now known as Central St. Martins.

column14: Mahatma Gandhi (1869-1948) stayed here in 1931
column16: Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi (1869-1948) often referred to as Mahatma Gandhi ("Great Soul") was the pre-eminent political and ideological leader of India during the Indian independence movement. Gandhi's model of non-violent fight for civil rights and freedom that he called satyagraha inspired movements across the world. It was here in 1931 that Gandhi stayed during negotiations between the British government and the Indian nation: Gandhi was the sole representative of the Indian National Congress (INC). The Gandhi-Irwin pact that was signed in March 1931 was effectively a truce, with Gandhi agreeing to end the civil disobedience movement by the INC.

column14: Sir Henry Morton Stanley (1841-1904) Explorer and Writer lived and died here * Welsh journalist and explorer famous for his exploration of Africa and his search for David Livingstone. Upon finding Livingstone, Stanley allegedly uttered the now-famous greeting, "Dr. Livingstone, I presume?"
column16: Sir Henry Morton Stanley (1841-1904) was a Welsh journalist and explorer. Stanley was employed by the founder of the New York Herald Tribune to find the Scottish missionary and explorer David Livingstone who was known to be in Africa but who had not been heard from for some time. The 7000 mile journey through Zanzibar was extremely perilous, but Stanley found Livingstone on 10 November 1871 near Lake Tanganyika and greeted him with the now famous phrase, "Doctor Livingstone, I presume?" Stanley continued to explore the Congo region of Africa until his death in 1904, and his work book "Through the Dark Continent" is considered an inspiration for Joseph Conrad's "Heart of Darkness."

column14: John McDouall Stuart (1815-1866) First Explorer to cross Australia lived and died here
column16: John McDouall Stuart (1815-1866) was a Scottish explorer, and the first man to successfully lead an expedition to traverse the Australian mainland. Born in Scotland in 1866 Stuart trained as civil engineer before emigrating to Australia in 1838. Stuart led a total of six expeditions with the successful south to north journey from Adelaide to Darwin completed in 1862. The town Alice Springs was originally named Stuart in his honour, before being changed in 1933. Stuart died here in London in 1866.

column14: Robert Falcon Scott (1868-1912) Antarctic explorer lived here
column16: Robert Falcon Scott (1868-1912) was a Royal Navy officer and explorer who led two expeditions to the Antarctic regions: the Discovery Expedition, 1901–04, and the ill-fated Terra Nova Expedition, 1910–13. During this second venture, Scott led a party of five which reached the South Pole on 17 January 1912, only to find that they had been preceded by Roald Amundsen's Norwegian expedition. On their return journey, Scott and his four comrades all perished from a combination of exhaustion, starvation and extreme cold. Scott's exploration of the Antarctic has made his name synonymous with the region, and he is regarded today as a brave and stoic leader, despite some errors on his part.

column14: Edward Adrian Wilson (1872-1912) Antarctic explorer and naturalist lived here
column16: Edward A Wilson (1872-1912) was a polar explorer and expedition artist. Wilson travelled on two Antarctic expeditions: Discovery 1901-1904 and Terra Nova 1910-1912, both under the leadership of Robert Falcon Scott. Wilson developed a love of the countryside and natural history as a young boy, and having studied at Cambridge and in London as a doctor, joined the Discovery expedition as junior surgeon, zoologist and expedition artist. He was Chief of the Scientific Staff of Scott's final expedition. Affectionately known as "Uncle Bill" by the men, Wilson was the confidant of many, respected for his judgement, mediatory skills and dedication to others. By all accounts, Wilson was probably Scott's closest comrade of the expedition.

column14: Charles 3rd Earl Stanhope 1753-1816Reformer and Inventor lived here * Invented the Stanhope printing press
column16: Charles Stanhope, 3rd Earl Stanhope aka Charles Mahon, 3rd Earl Stanhope FRS (3 August 1753 – 15 December 1816) was a British statesman and scientist. He was the father of the great traveller and Arabist Lady Hester Stanhope and brother-in-law of William Pitt the Younger. Stanhope was an accomplished scientist and inventor, inventing a printing press and lens which both bear his name.

column14: SIR CHARLES WHEATSTONE 1802-1875 Scientist and Inventor lived here * a major figure in the development of telegraphy, amongst other achievements
column16: Sir Charles Wheatstone (1802-1875) was an English scientist and inventor of many scientific breakthroughs of the Victorian era. As well as inventing the English concertina, the stereoscope and the Playfair cipher (an encryption technique), Wheatstone is perhaps best known for his contributions in the development of the Wheatstone bridge, which is used to measure unknown electrical resistance. He was also a major figure in the development of telegraphy. Following his death, Wheatstone's remains were brought to his house in Regent's Park, before being buried in Kensal Green Cemetery.

column14: SIR BENJAMIN THOMPSON COUNT RUMFORD 1753-1814 Inventor and Adventurer lived here
column16: Sir Benjamin Thompson, Count Rumford (1753-1814) was an American-born British physicist and inventor whose challenges to established theory were part of the nineteenth century revolution in thermodynamics. He also served as a Lieutenant-Colonel in the Loyalist forces in America during the American Revolutionary War. After the end of the war he moved to London where his administrative talents were recognized when he was appointed a full Colonel, and in 1784 received a knighthood from King George III. A prolific designer, he also drew designs for warships.

column14: DENNIS GABOR 1900-1979 Physicist and Inventor of Holography lived here
column16: Dennis Gabor (1900-1979) was a Hungarian-British electrical engineer and inventor, most notable for inventing holography, for which he later received the 1971 Nobel Prize in Physics. Holography is the technique used to produce holograms. Gabor was originally from Budapest and studied in Berlin before fleeing Nazi Germany in 1933. Settling in Britain, Gabor moved to London in 1948 to work at Imperial College London where he worked until retirement. Following the rapid development of lasers and a wide variety of holographic applications (e.g., art, information storage, and the recognition of patterns), Gabor achieved acknowledged success and worldwide attention during his lifetime.

column14: Joseph Aloysius Hansom 1803-1882 Architect, founder-editor of 'The Builder' and inventor of the Hansom Cab lived here
column16: Joseph Aloysius Hansom (26 October 1803 – 29 June 1882) was a prolific English architect working principally in the Gothic Revival style. As well as an accomplished architect and designer, Hansom invented the Hansom safety cab in 1834: an improved horse-drawn carriage that was fast, light and agile. Hansom also co-founded the eminent architectural journal "The Builder" in 1843 which still publishes today and is one of the oldest business-to-business magazines in the country.

column14: Lord William Thomspon (1824-1907) Physicist and Inventor lived here * Lord Kelvin, as he was known,  is widely known for realising that there was a lower limit to temperature, absolute zero; absolute temperatures are stated in units of kelvin in his honour
column16: William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin (1824-1907) was a mathematical physicist and engineer. At the University of Glasgow he did important work in the mathematical analysis of electricity and formulation of the first and second laws of thermodynamics, and did much to unify the emerging discipline of physics in its modern form. Lord Kelvin is widely known for realising that there was a lower limit to temperature, absolute zero; absolute temperatures are stated in units of kelvin in his honour. He also carried out significant work on the transatlantic telegraph project. Lord Kelvin spent some time in London and he is interred at Westminster Abbey, close-by the final resting place of Sir Isaac Newton.

column14: John Rae (1813-1893) Arctic explorer lived and died here * Reported the fate of the Franklin Expedition
column16: John Rae (1813-1693) was a Scottish doctor who explored northern Canada and surveyed parts of the Northwest Passage. Rae studied medicine in Edinburgh before working as a surgeon in Ontario. Rae is perhaps best known for reporting the fate of the Franklin Expedition, a doomed British voyage of Arctic exploration led by Captain Sir John Franklin that departed England in 1845 and became icebound, losing all 128 men. Although Rae gained notoriety for reporting this, he was not as famous as other contemporary explorers, despite being willing to adopt and learn the ways of the indigenous Arctic people.

column14: Sir James Clark Ross (1800-1862) Polar Explorer lived here * explored the eastern side of what is now known as James Ross Island, discovering and naming Snow Hill Island and Seymour Island, in the Antarctic
column16: Sir James Clark Ross (1800-1862) was a British naval officer and explorer. He explored the Arctic with his uncle Sir John Ross and Sir William Parry, first embarking on a controversial voyage in 1818 in search of the Northwest Passage (a sea route through the Arctic ocean above North America). Ross later led his own expedition to Antarctica in 1839 which charted much of the coastline of the continent. In 1841, James Ross discovered the Ross Sea, Victoria Land, and the volcanoes Mount Erebus and Mount Terror, which were named after the expedition's vessels, and the following year explored the eastern side of what is now known as James Ross Island, discovering and naming Snow Hill Island and Seymour Island.

column14: Sir Ernest Shackleton (1874-1922) Antarctic Explorer lived here
column16: Sir Ernest Henry Shackleton (1874-1922) was an Anglo-Irish polar explorer, one of the principal figures of the period known as the Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration. Gaining valuable experience on RF Scott's Discovery expedition 1901-1904, Shackleton went on to command three voyages of his own. The most famous expedition, Endurance 1914-1916, ended in near-disaster when the vessel became trapped in pack ice and was crushed. There followed a sequence of exploits, and an ultimate escape with no lives lost, thus securing Shackleton's heroic status. He died of a heart attack in 1921 while circumnavigating the Antarctic continent.

column14: In a house on this site lived from 1854-1875 SIR CHARLES LYELL Geologist and from 1876-1882 W.E. GLADSTONE Statesman
column16: This building first housed Sir Charles Lyell (1797-1875) a British lawyer who was the foremost geologist of his day. He is best known as the author of Principles of Geology, which popularised James Hutton's concepts of uniformitarianism – the idea that the earth was shaped by slow-moving forces still in operation today. Lyell was a close and influential friend of Charles Darwin. Following his death the house was occupied by William Ewart Gladstone (1809-1898). Gladstone was a British Liberal statesman who, in a career lasting over sixty years, served as Prime Minister four times (more than any other person). Gladstone is famous for his oratory, his rivalry with the Conservative leader Benjamin Disraeli and his poor relations with Queen Victoria.

column14: Thomas Young (1773-1829) Man of Science lived here * He is famous for having partly deciphered Egyptian hieroglyphics (specifically the Rosetta Stone) before Jean-François Champollion eventually expanded on his work. He was admired by, among others, Herschel and Einstein.
column16: Thomas Young (1773-1829) was an English polymath, scientist and Egyptologist. He is famous for having partly deciphered Egyptian hieroglyphics (specifically the Rosetta Stone) before Jean-François Champollion eventually expanded on his work. He was admired by, among others, Herschel, Helmholtz, Maxwell, and Einstein.Young made notable scientific contributions to the fields of vision, light, solid mechanics, energy, physiology, language, musical harmony and Egyptology. One of the most important contributions to science was to establish the wave theory of light - that light is not a particle, but rather emitted in all directions as a series of waves, rather like sound.

column14: SIR FRANCIS BEAUFORT 1774-1857 Admiral and Hydrographer lived here
column16: Rear-Admiral Sir Francis Beaufort (1774-1857) was an Irish hydographer and officer in Britain's Royal Navy. Beaufort had a lifelong keen awareness of the value of accurate charts for those risking the seas, having been shipwrecked himself at age fifteen due to a faulty chart, and his life's biggest accomplishments were in nautical charting. As a naval officer Beaufort commanded HMS Woolwich which was tasked with charting the Rio de la Plata estuary of South America. It was during his sea voyages that Beaufort developed the first versions of his Wind Force Scale and Weather Notation coding - now known as the Beaufort scale.

column14: JAMES SMITHSON 1764-1829 Scientist Founder of the Smithsonian Institution lived here
column16: James Smithson (1764-1829) was a British mineralogist and chemist. Not much is known about Smithson's life as his archive of collections, notebooks, diaries and correspondence was destroyed by fire in 1855 but it clear that he had a keen interest in minerals and the study of the natural world. He was made a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1787, then the youngest person to be so. A shrewd investor, Smithson bequeathed a small fortune to the United States of America upon his death to create "an establishment for the increase and diffusion of knowledge among men." It became the Smithsonian Institute.

column14: MAJOR-GENERAL WILLIAM ROY 1726-1790 Founder of the Ordnance Survey lived here
column16: Major-General William Roy FRS (1726 – 1790) was a Scottish military engineer, surveyor, and antiquarian. He was an innovator who applied new scientific discoveries and newly emerging technologies to the accurate geodetic mapping of Great Britain. It was Roy's advocacy and leadership that led to the creation of the Ordnance Survey in 1791, the year after his death. His technical work in the establishment of a surveying baseline won him the Copley Medal in 1785. His maps and drawings of Roman archaeological sites in Scotland were the first accurate and systematic study of the subject, and have not been improved upon even today. Roy was a Fellow of the Royal Society and a member of the Society of Antiquaries of London.

column14: THOMAS HENRY HUXLEY 1825-1895 Biologist Lived Here * Known for his advocacy of Evolution, In 1869 Huxley coined the term 'agnostic' to describe his own views on theology,
column16: Thomas Henry Huxley (1825-1895) was an English biologist, known as "Darwin's Bulldog" for his advocacy of Charles Darwin's theory of evolution. Huxley's famous 1860 debate with Samuel Wilberforce was a key moment in the wider acceptance of evolution, and in his own career. He was instrumental in developing scientific education in Britain, and fought against the more extreme versions of religious tradition. In 1869 Huxley coined the term 'agnostic' to describe his own views on theology, a term whose use has continued to the present day. Huxley had little formal schooling and taught himself almost everything he knew. He became perhaps the finest comparative anatomist of the latter 19th century.

column14: Sir AMBROSE FLEMING 1849-1945 Scientist and Electrical Engineer lived here * He is known for inventing the first thermionic valve or vacuum tube, the diode, then called the kenotron in 1904.[2] He is also famous for the left hand rule (for electric motors).
column16: Sir John Ambrose Fleming (1849-1945) was an English electrical engineer and physicist. As an engineering consultant for firms including Edison Telephone and the Marconi company, Fleming made a significant breakthrough in 1904 when he developed a device he called an "oscillation valve" which soon became known as the Fleming Valve and was an early type of diode. Today, descendants of the original valve (or vacuum tube) still play an important role in a range of applications. They can be found in the power stages of radio and television transmitters, in some high-end audio amplifiers, as detectors of optical and short wavelength radiation, and in sensitive equipment that must be "radiation-hard".

column14: SIR ISAAC NEWTON 1642-1727 Lived Here
column16: Sir Isaac Newton (1642-1727) was an English physicist, mathematician, astronomer, natural philosopher, alchemist, and theologian, who has been "considered by many to be the greatest and most influential scientist who ever lived." Newton's theory of universal gravitation - where motions of objects on Earth and of celestial bodies are governed by the same set of natural laws advanced the Scientific Revolution. Newton lived here when he was appointed warden of the Royal Mint in 1696; an appointment he took very seriously and campaigned against corruption and inefficiency in the organisation. In 1703, he was elected president of the Royal Society, an office he held until his death.

column14: HERTHA AYRTON 1854-1923 Physicist lived here 1903-1923 * In 1899, she was the first woman ever to read her own paper before the Institution of Electrical Engineers (IEE). Shortly thereafter, she was elected the first female member of the IEE.
column16: Hertha Ayrton (1854-1923) was an English engineer, mathematician and inventor. Ayrton was educated at Girton College, Cambridge and gained a degree from the University of London in 1881. Through her marriage to William Edward Ayrton, a teacher, she began investigations into the electric arc. In 1899, she was the first woman ever to read a paper before the Institution of Electrical Engineers (IEE) and was shortly thereafter elected the first female member of the IEE. Ayrton was agnostic, but kept close ties to the Jewish faith, establishing the Jewish League for Women Suffrage in 1912.

column14: LEONARD HUXLEY 1860-1933 JULIAN HUXLEY 1887-1975 ALDOUS HUXLEY 1894-1963 Men of Science and Letters lived here
column16: Three members of the great Huxley family lived here: Leonard Huxley (1860-1933) the most prominent son of Thomas Henry Huxley (the scientist and Darwin's greatest supporter), Sir Julian Huxley (1887-1975) and Aldous Huxley (1894-1963). Leonard was a teacher and writer whose major work was a biography of his father. Julian was a prominent zoologist, and was the first Director-General of UNESCO and also the co-founder of the World Wildlife Fund who did much to further Darwin's theory of evolution. Aldous was a novelist of great fame who wrote in an iconoclastic style that was often disenchanted and with a dystopian view, "Brave New World" being the most famous.

column14: Sir WILLIAM RAMSAY 1852-1916 Chemist Discoverer of the Noble Gases lived here 1887-1902
column16: Sir William Ramsay (1852-1916) was a Scottish chemist who is most famous for his work in discovering the noble gases. Ramsay was born in Glasgow, Scotland and studied at both Glasgow Academy and the University of Glasgow. After a period in Bristol, Ramsay was appointed chair of Chemistry at University College London in 1887. It was at UCL that his most celebrated discoveries were made - isolating a heavy component of air which did not appear to have any obvious chemical reactivity (he named this "argon"), then neon, krypton, xenon and helium discoveries in the following years. He received the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1904.

column14: SIR WILLIAM CROOKES 1832-1919 SCIENTIST lived here from 1880 until his death * He was a pioneer of vacuum tubes, inventing the Crookes tube
column16: Sir William Crookes (1832-1919) was a British chemist and physicist who attended the Royal College of Chemistry, London and who was a pioneer of vacuum tubes, inventing the Crookes tube. Crookes was born in London and roe to prominence as a chemist in the 1850s, working under AW Hofmann. It was at 7 Kensington Gardens, Crookes's home, that much of his most notable work was done. As well as discovering the chemical element thallium, Crookes also pioneered the use of vacuum tubes; he developed the Crookes radiometer becoming one of the first scientists to investigate what are known today as plasmas.

column14: Chaim Weizmann (1874-1952) Scientist and Statesman First President of the State of Israel lived here
column16: Chaim Weizmann (1874-1952) was a scientist and politician who became the first President of the State of Israel in 1949. Weizmann was born in Russia and studied in Switzerland before moving to Manchester as lecturer of Chemistry at the university. During WWI, he was credited with developing a method of producing acetone from maize; which was needed for the production of artillery shells. It was in London that Weizmann was successful in procuring from Arthur James Balfour the Balfour Declaration of 1917 in which the British government supported the creation of a Zionist state in Palestine.

column14: Sir NORMAN LOCKYER 1836-1920 Astronomer, Physicist and Founder of Nature lived here 1876-1920
column16: Norman Lockyer (1836-1920) was an English scientist and astronomer. It was in the 1860s that Lockyer became fascinated with electromagnetic spectroscopy (the study of the interaction between matter and radiated energy). Working in London, Lockyer observed an unknown element emitted from the sun which he named "helium" from the Greek word "Helios" meaning sun. As well as his astronomical work, Lockyer also founded the journal "Nature" in 1869, to facilitate the transmission of ideas between scientists.

column6: The Elms, 29-32 Clapham Common North Side
column14: Sir Charles Barry (1795-1860) Architect lived and died here * best known for his role in the rebuilding of the Palace of Westminster (also known as the Houses of Parliament) in London during the mid-19th century
column16: Sir Charles Barry (1795-1860) was an English architect who is best known for his role in the rebuilding of the Palace of Westminster, also known as the Houses of Parliament. Barry travelled extensively throughout Europe and the Middle East from 1817-1820, before working for the Church Commissioners in the Gothic Revival architecture style. Barry made a significant contribution to the Italian Renaissance garden fashions of Victorian Britain, inspired by his travels. Barry's most significant work was the design of the Palace of Westminster after it was destroyed by fire in 1834. He also remodelled Trafalgar Square. Barry lived in Clapham until his death in 1860.

column14: John Francis Bentley (1839-1902) Architect lived here * most famous work is the Westminster Cathedral in London, England,
column16: John Francis Bentley (1839-1902) was an English ecclesiastical architect. Bentley was born in Doncaster and trained as an architect in the offices of Henry Clutton. Bentley's most imporant commission was that of the Westminster Cathedral in 1894. As he had mastered the neo-Gothic and Byzantine Revivalist styles thoughout his career, Bentley decided to travel to Italy to study some of the most important Byzantine-influenced cathedrals, such as St Mark's Basilica in Venice, which provided much of the inspiration for Westminster Cathedral.

column14: Lancelot 'Capability' BROWN 1716-1783 Landscape Architect lived here 1764-1783
column16: Lancelot "Capability" Brown (1716-1783) was a pioneering landscape architect. Brown began his career at Stowe, Buckinghamshire, under William Kent, one of the founders of the new English style of landscape garden. As a proponent of this style, Brown became quickly sought after by families all over the country. Brown was coined "Capability" because he would often tell his clients that their estates had great "capability" for improvement. It is estimated that Brown worked on over 170 gardens,  and in 1764 he was appointed master gardener at Hampton Court Palace. He is today regarded as "England's greatest gardener."

column14: WILLIAM BUTTERFIELD 1814-1900 Architect lived here * a Gothic Revival architect and associated with the Oxford Movement (or Tractarian Movement). He is noted for his use of polychromy
column16: William Butterfield (1814-1900) was an English architect who pioneered the Gothic Revivalist style of the Victorian era. Butterfield was born to non-conformist parents in London and after training with several notable architects he set up his own practice in 1840. Butterfield's style was heavily influenced by the Cambridge Camden Society, of which he was a member, who promoted the study of Gothic Architecture. Butterfield was also famous for his use of polychromy (the multiple use of colours in brickwork) which can be seen in his design of Rugby School in Warwickshire and Keble College at Oxford.

column14: Colen Campbell (1676-1729) Architect lived and died here *  credited as a founder of the Georgian style
column16: Colen Campbell (1676-1729) was a pioneering Scottish architect. Having initially trained as a lawyer in Edinburgh, Campbell decided to move to London to train as an architect. His highly influential published work "Vitruvius Britannicus" which appeared in three volumes between 1715 and 1725 was instrumental in popularising the neo-Palladium style which came to dominate early eighteenth century architecture. Under the guidance of Lord Burlington, Campbell worked on buildings such as the Royal Academy in London and Stourhead in Wiltshire. Campbell is widely credited as one of the founders of the Georgian style of architecture.

column6: Central School of Arts and Crafts, Southampton Row
column14: William Richard Lethaby (1857-1931) Architect and first principal of this school in 1896-1911
column16: William Richard Lethaby (1857-1931) was an English architect whose ideas were influential on the late Arts and Crafts and early Modern movements. In 1894 Lethaby was appointed Art Inspector to the Technical Education Board of the newly formed London County Council. Here he had a pioneering role in developing education in the fine and practical arts, most notably as the founder of the Central School of Arts and Crafts in 1896. His most significant innovations lay in breaking down academic barriers between design (perceived as an artistic and intellectual pursuit) and production (widely perceived as the less sophisticated activity of the craftsman or artisan). Lethaby believed that this was an artificial distinction and sought to have both taught as equally valuable parts of the process of producing a high quality end-product.

column14: Frank Matcham 1854-1920 Theatre Architect lived here 1895-1904
column16: Frank Matcham (1854-1920) was a pioneering English architect who desgned over 200 theatres throughout Britain between 1890-1915. Matcham inherited his father-in-law's architectural practice in 1878, from where his most famous designs were made - these include the Hackney Empire, London Coliseum and the Victoria Palace theatre. By the outbreak of the First World War no significant town was without its theatre or music hall. Matcham's success lay in his innovative steel cantilevers which, when used in constructing the theatre space, allowed balconies to be built without pillars, thus improving sight lines for the audience. He also set new standards in safety and his work was extremely popular with the public.

column14: Here lived and died JOHN LOUGHBOROUGH PEARSON 1817-1897 and later SIR EDWIN LANDSEER LUTYENS 1869-1944 Architects
column16: Two pioneering architects of the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries lived in this house. The first inhabitant was John Loughborough Pearson (1817-1897) who was one of the foremost Gothic Revivalist architects of the late-Victorian era. He was renowned for his work on churches and cathedrals in Britain, including a proficiency for the art of vaulting. His most famous work is Truro Cathedral. He lived for much of his life in Mansfield Street, London, and was awarded the RIBA gold medal in 1880. The second inhabitant was Edwin Lutyens (1869-1944) who was an English architect and designer. Through a long industrious career Lutyens contributed much to the architecture of the British nation and Commonwealth and is often referred to as "the greatest English architect of all time." Born in London in 1869, Lutyens studied at what is now the Royal College of Art before starting his own practice in 1885. Lutyens is closely associated with the commemoration of the First World War through his designs, most notably the Cenotaph in Whitehall. Lutyens was also commissioned to design New Delhi, which was chosen to replace the seat of the British Indian government in 1912 and is known today as "Lutyens Delhi."

column14: RED HOUSE built in 1859-1860 by Philip Webb, architect for WILLIAM MORRIS poet and artist who lived here 1860-1864
column16: Red House in Bexleyheath is one of the most important buildings in the history of the Arts and Crafts movement and of nineteenth century architecture. It was designed by William Morris and Philip Webb in 1859 as a home for Morris and his wife Jane. The house was designed to be a "palace of art" for Morris and his friends; the windows and wall paintings were created by Edward Burne-Jones. Morris and his family lived for only five years in Red House and were forced to sell for financial reasons. Now owned by the National Trust the house is preserved to give an insight into the truly iconic work of its designers and artists of the time.

column14: RED HOUSE built in 1859-1860 by Philip Webb, architect for WILLIAM MORRIS poet and artist who lived here 1860-1865

column14: Sir Giles Gilbert Scott (1880-1960 Architect designed this house and lived here 1926-1960 * an English architect known for his work on such buildings as Liverpool Cathedral and Battersea Power Station and designing the iconic red telephone box
column16: Sir Giles Gilbert Scott (1880-1960) was an English architect. The grandson of Sir George Gilbert Scott (designer of St Pancras Hotel) Scott trained as an architect from 1899-1902 and aged 21 won a competition to design Liverpool Anglican Cathedral, the construction of which lasted his whole life. Another signature building of Scott's is Battersea Power Station which was completed in 1933. By far the most recognisable of Scott's designs is the red telephone box. Again winning a competition, this time for the General Post Office, Scott submitted the design for "Kiosk No. 2" in 1924 which featured a classical domed roof and was subsuequently installed in every town and village in the country. Scott desgned and lived in this house in Paddington.

column14: Luke howard (1772-1864) Namer of clouds lived and died here
column16: Luke Howard (1772-1864) was a British manufacturing chemist and an amateur meteorolgist. Howard was a businessman and trained pharmacist: he founded a pharmaceutical company in 1797 which became Howard and Sons in 1856. Howard's main passion, however, was meteorology and he made comprehensive recordings of the weather from 1801. In his 1803 essay "Essay on the Modification of Clouds" Howard first proposed the three principal categories of clouds: cumulus, stratus and cirrus, as well as several sub-categories. He was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society on 8 March 1821, and despite having no formal scientific education is known today as the "father of meteorology."

column14: Thomas Henry Wyatt 1807-1880 Architect lived and died here *  elected President of the Royal Institute of British Architects 1870-73[3] and awarded their Royal Gold Medal for Architecture in 1873
column16: Thomas Henry Wyatt (1807-1880) was an Irish British architect who had a prolific and distinguished career, being elected President of the Royal Institute of British Architects in 1870 and awarded their Royal Gold Medal in 1873. He lived and practised in Great Russell Street until his death in 1880. Wyatt is famous for designing many buildings of the nineteenth century, in styles ranging from Italianate to Gothic.

column14: Sir Christopher Wren 1632-1723 Architect lived here
column16: Sir Christopher Wren (1632-1723) was an English architect, astronomer, geometer and mathematician-physicist. Wren is widely associated with the major rebuilding programme following the Great Fire of London in 1666, which included St Paul's Cathedral in the City of London. As well as St Paul's, Wren was also responsible for the design of, amongst others, the south front of Hampton Court Palace, Greenwich Naval College, Kensington Palace and the library at Trinity College, Cambridge. Wren is also associated with the formation of the Royal Society of which he was President from 1680 to 1682. Wren was resident of Hampton Court during the extensive restoration commissioned by King William III and Queen Mary II in 1689.

column14: Alfred Waterhouse 1830-1905 Architect lived here * He is perhaps best known for his design for the Natural History Museum in London,
column16: Alfred Waterhouse (1830 – 1905) was a British architect, particularly associated with the Victorian Gothic Revival architecture. He is perhaps best known for his design for the Natural History Museum in London, and Manchester Town Hall, although he also built a wide variety of other buildings throughout the country. Financially speaking, Waterhouse was probably the most successful of all Victorian architects. Though expert within Neo-Gothic, Renaissance revival, and Romanesque revival styles, Waterhouse never limited himself to a single architectural style. Waterhouse designed and lived in his house on New Cavendish Street.

column14: C.F.A. Voysey 1857-1941 Architect and Designer lived here
column16: CFA Voysey (1857-1941) was an English architect and furniture and textile designer. Voysey's early work was as a designer of wallpapers, fabrics and furnishings in a simple Arts and Crafts style, but he is renowned as the architect of a number of notable country houses. He was born in Yorkshire in 1857 and studied with JP Seddon in 1874 and then for a year under George Devey. Voysey's early work was mainly in textiles and wallpaper, and he was one of the first designers to fully understand and appreciate the significance of industrial design. His architectural work was heavily influenced by English vernacular sources of the 16th and early 17th centuries and eschewed the complexities of Victorian design.

column14: Michael Ventris 1922-1956 Architect and Decipherer of Linear B script lived here
column16: Michael Ventris (1922-1956) was an English architect and classical scholar who, along with John Chadwick, was responsible for the decipherment of Linear B. Ventris was educated in Switzerland and at Stowe School. He could speak six European languages and read Latin and classical Greek. He enrolled at the Architectural Association School of Architecture in 1940 and graduated in 1948, after interrupting his training to serve as a navigator in the Royal Air Force. Ventris was awarded an OBE in 1955 for "services to Mycenaean paleography." A few years after deciphering Linear B in 1951-1953, Ventris, who lived in Hampstead, died in a car crash, aged 34.

column14: Thomas Smith Tait (1882-1954) Architect lived here * Art Deco architect
column16: Thomas Smith Tait (1882-19545) was a prominent Scottish Modernist architect. Having attended Glasgow School of Art, Tait was recruited by John Burnet & Sons in 1902, where he was made partner in 1918. It was at the practice that Tait produced his most notable works - these included: the pylons for Sydney Harbour Bridge, St Andrew's House, Edinburgh and the later phases of Selfridge's, London. Tait also designed several modernist houses in St John's Wood as well as war memorials following the First World War. Tait lived in Gates House in Hampstead from 1928 which he tactfully extended and fitted out with Art Deco features.

column14: Sir Robert Smirke (1831-1912) Architect lived here * Smirke designed the main block and facade of the British Museum, perhaps his best-known work
column16: Sir Robert Smirke (1780-1867) was an English architect famous for his Greek Revival style. The largest and best known of Smirke's buildings is the main block and façade of London's British Museum. Smirke was invited to design the museum in 1820, and construction began in 1823. The purpose of the developement of the museum site was to create a building surrounding a large central courtyard and due to lack of funds the work was split into phases. Like many architects of his time, Smirke was greatly influenced by the buildings and palaces he visited during his "Grand Tour" of 1801-1805. The main facade of the British Museum, and its great colonnade of 44 Greek iconic columns are loosely based on those of Athena Polias at Priene, the ancient Greek city of Ionia.

column14: Dante Gabriel Rossetti 1828-1882 poet and painter and Algernon Charles Swinburne 1837-1909 poet lived here
column16: In 1862 Dante Gabriel Rossetti (1828-1882) movd into Queen's House, 17 Cheyne Walk in Chelsea and lived there with his brother William Rossetti (1829-1919) and Algernon Charles Swinburne (1837-1909). Rossetti took a liking to the house and lived here, mostly by himself, until his death in 1882. In the house Rossetti, the founder of the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood, collected paintings and furniture, although his residency was a period of mental instability and decline. Rossetti had been politely cut out of William Morris's firm and his recent collection of poetry had been badly received by critics.

column14: Sir Robert Peel 1750-1830 Manufacturer and reformer and his son Sir Robert Peel 1788-1850 Prime Minister Founder of the Metropolitan Police lived here
column16: Sir Robert Peel (1750-1830) was a British politican and industrialist and one of the early textile manufacturers of the Industrial Revolution. His eldest son, Sir Robert Peel (1788-1850) was British Conservative statesman who served as Prime Minister  from 1834 to 1835, and again from 1841 to 1846. It was as Home Secretary that Peel the Younger formed the Metropolitan Police Force in 1829, the model of modern police forces throughout the country.

column14: Sir Robert Walpole 1676-1745 Prime Minister and his son Horace Walpole 1717-1797 Connoisseur and Man of Letters lived here
column16: Sir Robert Walpole (1676-1745) was a British statesman who is generally regarded as having been the first Prime Minister of Great Britain. Such was his influence in the Cabinet and the politics of his day that Walpole was gifted 10 Downing Street by King George II. His son Horace Walpole (1717-1797) was an English art historian, man of letters, antiquarian and Whig politician. He is now largely remembered for Strawberry Hill, the home he built in Twickenham, south-west London where he revived the Gothic style some decades before his Victorian successors, and for his Gothic novel, The Castle of Otranto. Along with the book, his literary reputation rests on his Letters, which are of significant social and political interest.

column14: Here lived Philip Henry Gosse 1810-1888 Zoologist Sir Edmund Gosse 1849-1928 Writer and Critic born here
column16: Philip Henry Gosse (1810 – 1888) was an English naturalist and populariser of natural science, virtually the inventor of the seawater aquarium, and a painstaking innovator in the study of marine biology. He lived in De Beauvoir Town throughout his career, and it was from there that he travelled abroad to study. Edmund Gosse, Philip's son, was born in 1849. Edmund is perhaps best known for his memoir "Father and Son," published in 1907, which focuses on the relationship between a sternly religious father and a son's coming of age and rejection of his father's fundamentailst religion. Although recent interpretations have rejected the tyrannical depiction of Gosse the senior, it is still a powerful tale of late Victorian family life.

column14: Oscar Wilde (1854-1900) wit and dramatist lived here
column16: Oscar Wilde (1854-1900) was an Irish writer and poet who became one of the most well known figures of the late-Victorian era for his plays, biting wit and flamboyant character. At the height of Wilde's fame and success, while "The Importance of Being Earnest" (1895) was still on stage in London, Wilde had the Marquess of Queensberry, the father of his lover, Lord Alfred Douglas, prosecuted for libel. The trial unearthed evidence that caused Wilde to drop his charges and led to his own arrest, and trial for gross indecency. He was imprisoned for two years' hard labour. Upon his release he fled to Paris where he died destitute in 1900. He was first confronted  by Queensberry and then arrested on Tite Street, Chelsea.

column14: In this house occupied by Thomas Davies, bookseller, Dr. Samuel Johnson first met James Boswell in 1763
column16: Thomas Davies (1712-1785) was a Scottish bookseller and author. He studied at the University of Edinburgh and having acted on the stage opened a bookshop in Covent Garden. It was at 8 Russell Street that Davies first introduced Dr Samuel Johnson (1709-1784) to James Boswell (1740-1795). This meeting would lead to the publication of "The Life of Samuel Johnson" in 1791 by James Boswell which is regarded as the greatest biography in the English language. Boswell's surname has passed into the English language as a term (Boswell, Boswellian, Boswellism) for a constant companion and observer, especially one who records those observations in print. In A Scandal in Bohemia, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's character Sherlock Holmes affectionately says of Dr. Watson, who narrates the tales, "I am lost without my Boswell."

column14: Sir Marc Isambard Brunel 1769-1849 and Isambard Kingdom Brunel 1806-1859 civil engineers lived here
column16: Sir Marc Isambard Brunel (1769-1849) was a French-born engineer who settled in England. His son Isambard Kingdom Brunel (1806-1859) was also an engineer who worked his father on the building of the Thames Tunnel from Rotherhithe to Wapping. Brunel the younger is today regarded as one of the most pioneering engineers of all time, for although not all of his projects were successful, they contained innovative solutions to long-standing engineering problems. Brunel the younger built the first major British railway, the Great Western Railway from London to Bristol, a series of transatlantic steamships and numerous bridges and tunnels.

column14: James Glaisher 1809-1909 Astronomer, Meteorologist and pioneer of weather forecasting lived here
column16: James Glaisher (1809-1903) was an English meteorologist and aeronaut. Glaisher was born in London and was appointed Superintendent of the Department of Meteorology and Magnetism at the Royal Greenwich Observatories from 1835-1869 and was a founder member of the Meteorological Society. He is perhaps most famous as a pioneering balloonist - Glaisher made numerous ascents between 1862-1866 to measure the atmosphere's humidity and temperature at its highest levels. His ascent on September 5, 1862 broke the world record for altitude, but he passed out around 8,800 metres before a reading could be taken, estimates suggest it may have been as high as 10,900 metres (2,052 metres higher than Mt Everest).

column14: Frank Pick 1878-1941 Pioneer of Good Design for London Transport lived here
column16: Frank Pick (1878-1941) was a British transport administrator. Pick rose through the corporate ranks of the Underground Electric Railway Company of London (UERL) to become managing director in 1928. It was during the early stages of Pick's career at UERL that he began work on developing a strong brand identity and visual style for which the London Underground later became famous. From standardisation of signage, to commissioning the Johnston "Underground" typeface, Pick's work helped increase passenger numbers and create some of the most iconic imagery of London's transport system. He is now regarded as a pioneer of good design, and one of the most important commissioners of art in Britain.

column14: Gavin Turk sculptor worked here 1989-1991
column16: Gavin Turk (1967-present) is a British artist and scupltor. He is often associated with the loose group of visual artists, the Young British Artists (YBAs). Turk gained notority in 1991 when, as his submission for his MA show at the Royal Academy of Art, he unveiled "Cave" which consisted of a whitewashed wall with a single blue plaque that read: "Gavin Turk, Sculptor worked here 1989-1991." Famously, Turk's tutors refused to award him a degree, effectively flunking the artist. Critics have since interpreted Turk's "Cave" as indicative of his self-obsession: he commemorates himself before his career has truly begun, yet paradoxically launches his career at the same time.

column14: Charles Dickens 1812-1870 Novelist lived here
column16: Charles Dickens (1812-1870) was an English writer, generally considered to be the greatest novelist of the Victorian period and responsible for some of English literature's most iconic novels and characters. His family were thrust into poverty when his father was imprisoned for bad debt and Charles was sent to work in a factory. Training as a journalist Dickens soon began writing serialised stories for weekly publications - this leant his stories a particular rhythm. Dickens and his family lived at 48 Doughty Street from 1837 to 1839, and it was here that his wife Catherine's sister Mary died in his arms after a brief illness. She became a character in many of his books.
